title: Phillips to Auction Norman Rockwell’s Iconic ‘Before the Shot’
text:
A version of the painting appeared on the cover of The Saturday Evening Post on March 15, 1958.

Text size

A nostalgic and humorous nod to American culture in the 1950s, Norman Rockwell’s iconic Before the Shot depicts a child waiting for a needle in a doctor’s office, while skeptically inspecting the physician’s credentials on the wall. “I guess everyone has sat in the doctor's office and examined his diplomas, wondering how good a doctor he was,” Rockwell once said. A version of the painting appeared on the cover of The Saturday Evening Post on March 15, 1958.

“Norman Rockwell is one of the greatest visual storytellers of the 20th century and these stories are as relevant and powerful today as they were when Rockwell painted them,” says Elizabeth Goldberg, Phillips ’ senior international specialist of American Art and deputy chairwoman, Americas. “Before the Shot is one of his most recognizable images and a prime example of his unmatched ability to capture a story with a single image.”

Rockwell painted the work from a series of photographs he methodically staged inside the office of Dr. Donald Campbell, his personal physician in Stockbridge, Mass., which was Rockwell’s home from 1953 until his death in 1978. Dr. Campbell served as the model for the doctor, and 8-year-old Eddie Locke, whom Rockwell chose right from the lunchroom at local Stockbridge Plain Elementary School, posed as the patient. Eddie would later go on to model for Rockwell’s The Runaway.

“Rockwell’s work is imbued with emotion and has a timelessness that has made him one of the most sought-after artists of the 20th century,” Goldberg says.

The artist often preferred painting regular people rather than professional models as subjects, which gave his paintings a true sense of middle-class, post-war life in America. He also knew first hand the reluctance of children visiting the doctor, since Rockwell was raising three young sons at the time.

Upon completion of the painting, Rockwell gifted it to Dr. Campbell, who sold it through Bernard Danenberg —Rockwell’s primary dealer at the time—in 1968 to the current owner’s father, Goldberg says. It was Danenberg who organized the artist’s first major exhibition.

The family, who wishes to remain anonymous, has had it in their collection since then. The work had been loaned to the Norman Rockwell Museum, where it hung for the last 13 years.

Before the Shot will be offered as a part of Phillips’ upcoming 20th Century & Contemporary Art sale on Nov. 14 in New York. It’s not only the first time that a work by Rockwell will appear in an Evening Sale of 20th Century & Contemporary Art, but it’s also the first time that a Rockwell painting will be offered at Phillips.

Other highlights from sale include Joan Miró’s Paysan catalan inquiet par le passage d'un vol d'oiseaux, Pablo Picasso’s Femme assise dans un fauteuil, and Morris Louis’ Singing from the Collection of Florence Knoll Bassett. Works by Andy Warhol, Jean-Michel Basquiat, and Roy Lichtenstein will also be offered at the sale.

“This auction marks the first time that Norman Rockwell will be offered in an Evening Sale of 20th Century & Contemporary Art beside these blue-chip artists,” Goldberg says. “We are proud to present Rockwell alongside these 20th century masters, a place we believe he rightfully belongs.”
description: The painting is expected to fetch between $2.5 million to $4.5 million
